Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2008 09:32AM Believer0711 wrote: Hi BabyDoll32732, I had a stereotactically-guided core needle biopsy on 11/9/07. They will numb the area where the tissue/specimen will be taken. Mine was stereotactic, so I laid on my stomach, they elevated the bed (with a hole for my boobie), and the radiologist took core specimens from underneath. I took tylenol before and after the biopsy. It takes about an hour or so, and you can drive yourself after. It is important that they take specimens so they can correctly diagnose those suspicious masses. Not all masses are bad, and not all biopsies end in surgery. Deep breaths, try to relax, do some shopping, have a girls night out, and don't worry :->. I pray everything goes well. God bless, Aurora

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 07:42PM Believer0711 wrote: My first diagnosis was multi-focal DCIS on the left breast - which is Stage 0 at that time. Mastectomy was the recommended treatment because the DCIS is in half of the breast. During surgery, pathologist found that there are 2 small invasive tumors around the DCIS. So my bs had to take 8 lymph nodes. Thank God, clear margins and lymph nodes. But it is now Stage 1. The fact that you caught it at this stage is very good. Are you also having MRI and PET scans? My PET scan is clear, meaning no other organs are affected. The MRI will also help confirm other suspicious tumors. Make sure you get copies of all the test results. It helps to have them in case you need to get second opinions. I pray everything goes well. Please keep us posted. God bless, Aurora

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2008 12:14AM - edited Feb 15, 2008 12:15AM by Believer0711 Hi ladies, The Unknowns are definitely a killer! So, I thought i'd share my experience this way---  Day 1 - first TC of 4 rounds, through IV (no port) for 2.5 hours Night 1 - Major headache Day 2 - Neulasta shot on my stomach (no pain!) instead of arm Night 2 - Minor headache, fatigue Day 3 - No problems Day 4 - Fatigue, stayed home Day 5 - Stiff neck and throat, gigantic headache, puffy face Day 6-7 - Bones started to hurt bad; took 2 hydrocodone every 6 hours (helped a lot!), but made me nauseous, so I took anti-nausea pill -- asked doc/nurse to make sure it's ok Day 8 - bloodwork showed good blood stats, but very very high white blood count!!! Doc will reduce Neulasta dose next time, since I don't need that much. This will reduce the bone pains. Each day, I drank 8-10 glasses of fluids, lots of fruits and veggies, boost drinks, and vitamin supplements -- which helped my immune system. I stopped taking stool softener (Senna) on Day 4 because I was having cramps. I've used Miracle Fiber (powder) from VitaminShoppe which is more gentle. I'm ready for my next treatment. Just want this over with, so we can move on. Ladies, we will survive this!!! God bless, Aurora

God bless us all, Aurora

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 10:22PM Believer0711 wrote: Hi ladies, had my first chemo today (Taxotere and Cytoxan) and it wasn't that bad at all. Praise God! I didn't need the port, so got it done through IV on my arm. ONE DOWN!!! CookieOkie, I'm so happy your first treatment went well. Yey! NobleAnna007, you'll get through this too - I believe it! Hydrate yourself beginning the day before chemo. Lots of liquids. And bring mittens to keep your hands warm, a favorite blanket and maybe a travel pillow. Picked up a nice wig today, and got some freebies from the Cancer Resource Center at the hospital. They gave me a free wig, scarf, turban, etc. They also give out surgibras for free. So if you don't feel like spending (they can be pricey), make sure you ask your breast surgeon where to get them. The only part that wasn't too good -- I was on my period!!! Really suxx. I also had my period on the day of my surgery. But other than that, everything's ok. Praying for quick recovery for all. Stay healthy dear friends! God bless, Aurora

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 06:07PM - edited Mar 4, 2008 06:08PM by Believer0711 Hi everyone, Day 6 for me, and so far still doing well. Yey. I feel a muscle twitch here and there, and the tips of my fingers feel so dry, but nothing annoying. I went to see my bs today for followup, and she was so surprised that I can stretch/move my arm 100%. I had 8 lymph nodes removed, and she didn't expect that I'd be able to move it freely so soon. Also, the stitches on my back are healing wonderfully, and my expander is symmetrical with my good breast. I can't get anything done. Arrgh. Oh, my scalp was so sensitive today. Ouch. Anybody had that feeling?  Rachel, I also got free scarves, wig, etc from ACS. They're cute, and don't cost a thing hehe. That's a great resource. I would really like to volunteer in those places when I'm fully recovered. Can't wait! Patricia, i enjoyed your list. There are really a lot of things to be thankful for. Donna, our fridge is still full! I'll be back, Aurora

Ladies, I pray each night, that God will continue to heal us and strengthen us. Love and blessings, Aurora

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 02:12PM Believer0711 wrote: Rose, I cut them rectangular or square, depending on size and pattern. If square, 30x30 (inches) is a generous size. Hem it, fold into a triangle, tie the 2 ends over the pointed side of triangle, then pouff it a little at the back/top so it's not too flat. I love the rectangular too, because you can make it long enough to hang on your back, or over one shoulder. Wear them just a little above the eyebrows for drama :-> Chris, I've also cut hubby's old tee-shirts into bandanas. They're bigger so you can make 2 pieces from each shirt. They're so soft, I use them at home, to bed, under straw hat while gardening. Bridget, I think you should switch back and forth depending on the temp - surprise them with your new styles!!! Remember the make-up too. A little color does make a lot of difference. I noticed that my eyes always look tired, and face color just looks blah - so I make sure I put makeup on.  Have fun ladies!!!!

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2008 12:08PM - edited Apr 4, 2008 03:53PM by Believer0711 Patty, what's diep again? I had the latissimus dorsi flap with expanders/implants because it has the quickest recovery time, from what I've heard and read. Ps said, I didn't have enough tummy fat to work with anyway - so for my size/build, lat flap was the way to go. I was back in the gym on my 3rd-4th week. You play tennis right? I have heard women who went back to tennis without problems. But again, that varies by individual. I talked to 3 ps before deciding, and the night before surg I still wasn't sure hehe. But I did it, and very happy with the results.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 05:31PM - edited Apr 11, 2008 05:35PM by Believer0711 Ladies, do the happy dance with me!!!! This is where you put your arms straight out at chest level, your feet about 12-inches apart, then you make a circle infront you with your arms, while the hips sway. Are you feeling it? It's official, I am D-O-N-E!!!! I think I'm going to consider myself an alumnus of this thread, which means I will keep in touch and hopefully we'll get a reunion in person someday. Thank you all for the congrats!!!! I don't think I would never have made it without you guys. This is the only graduation where cheating is allowed hehe. I copy and cheat from your comments, and it's ok. I love it! Chris, the nerves went away when I got there. BP 115/62, Heartbeat 80, blood counts were low, but good enough for the chemo. They had to give me a rbc boost, because my count was .6 below. Got my neulasta today and gave my nurse a candle holder that says "To A Wonderful Nurse". We just about cried as we hugged :-<  I'll meet with the onc after 3 weeks to talk about the hormone treatment, which he says, will be easy . Hmm, guess I'll find out. Love you guys, and I always pray that you'll get through this with as little discomfort as possible and that we never have to go through this again, EVERRR!!! God bless us all, Aurora
